Award.AwardTitle: NSF/CBMS Regional Conference on Higher Representation Theory-June 19-23, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support a five-day CBMS conference on "Higher representation theory of Kac-Moody algebras" at North Carolina State University in June 2014 with Raphael Rouquier as the principal speaker. The theory of Kac-Moody Lie algebras and their quantum analogs is a timely topic with various applications to other branches of mathematics and theoretical physics. Major developments have been focused on the categorification program which realizes key algebraic structures, such as canonical bases, in terms of category of modules based on combinatorial, algebraic or geometric structures. Categorification can provide deeper understanding of the original algebraic structures and obtain new structures. In categorification of quantum enveloping algebras, Khovanov-Lauda and Rouquier independently introduced the KLR algebra.

As one of the inventors and a leading practitioner in this field, Professor Rouquier will give ten lectures on the subject which aim to introduce workshop participants, including graduate students, to current research and chart possible future directions. Prof. Rouquier will also write up a monograph of the CBMS lectures after the conference. The conference expects to gather about 40 participants. An additional five speakers are invited to assist Professor Rouquier's lectures and to talk about categorification and higher representation theory. The conference will encourage participation from women, minorities, and persons with disabilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant supports a Regional Conference Board Conference (CBMS) at North Carolina State University during July 6-10, 2015 on Higher Representation Theory. During the last several decades, CBMS conferences have aimed to sponsor leading mathematicians to lecture on some of the most active research areas annually. 

      The current CBMS conference in Raleigh featured a series of 10 lectures by Professor Raphael Rouquier from University of California in Los Angeles. The short course gave a thorough treatment on categorification of quantum Kac-Moody algebras and their highest weight representations through the Khovanov-Lauda-Rouquier (KLR) algebras or the quiver Hecke algebras.

      The conference has a great impact on the broad mathematical community by making available the lectures of a co-founder of the KLR algebras to graduate students and young researchers.  Many important recent advances in representation theory have been centered on the topics presented at the conference.

      Professor Rouquier's lectures have been well-received by participants. His talks gave a comprehensive introduction to the Categorification program for Kac-Moody algebras. He started witha very intuitive and stimulating introduction to Chuang-Rouquier categorification of the 3-dimensional simple Lie algebra and explained the main ideas behind the passage from ordinary Lie algebras to the quantized Kac-Moody algebras.

      These materials represented one of the most active areas in representation theory and quantum groups. The categorification program started by Khovanov-Lauda and Rouquier has spread to many related areas in algebra and geometric representation theory. In the last part of his lectures, Professor Rouquier also explained the geometric representation theory, crystal graphs, quiver varieties in relation to the 2-Kac Moody algebras. In short, Professor Rouquier's lectures showcased the state of the art in one of the most active research areas in mathematics.

      There are also eight other mathematicians giving talks to supplement Prof. Rouquier's lectures. Some of these lectures touched on other aspects of categorification and provided assistance to the participants to understand Prof. Rouquier's lectures. We also held informal discussion sessions for participants to interact with Prof. Rouquier and other experts.
